title: Automating Movement
description: Learn to write code to automate your movements

preDialogues.name: Maru
preDialogues.content: You're absolutely right - clicking buttons for every single action won't work. That's where PROGRAMMING comes in!

preDialogues.name: Maru
preDialogues.content: Exactly! Instead of doing everything manually, we can write CODE to automate tasks. Let me show you the terminal.

preDialogues.name: Maru
preDialogues.content: Click on the QUICK PROGRAM button (looks like a terminal icon) or click directly on yourself to open the programming interface!

postDialogues.name: Qubit
postDialogues.content: Okay, I see it. It's... blank.

postDialogues.name: Maru
postDialogues.content: Perfect! That's because we're starting from scratch. Let me explain what each part does.

phases.title: Understanding Code Structure
phases.description: Learn the basics of code syntax

preDialogues.name: Maru
preDialogues.content: Alright, coding lesson time! Every program starts with a MAIN FUNCTION. Think of it as the entry point - where your code begins.

preDialogues.name: Maru
preDialogues.content: Type this exactly: 'def main():' then press ENTER. 'def' means 'define', and we're defining a function called 'main'.

preDialogues.name: Qubit
preDialogues.content: Why the colon at the end?

preDialogues.name: Maru
preDialogues.content: Great question! The colon (:) tells Python 'hey, here comes a block of code that belongs to this function'. Everything indented after it is INSIDE the function.

preDialogues.name: Maru
preDialogues.content: Now, press SPACE or TAB four times to indent, then type 'pass' and press ENTER. 'pass' is a placeholder that says 'nothing here yet'.

preDialogues.name: Maru
preDialogues.content: For now, just focus on this: CODE INSIDE THE FUNCTION MUST BE INDENTED. That's how Python knows what belongs together!

postDialogues.name: Qubit
postDialogues.content: So... 'def main():' creates the function, and everything indented is inside it?

postDialogues.name: Maru
postDialogues.content: Exactly! You're a natural. Now let's make it DO something!

preDialogues.name: Maru
preDialogues.content: Now for the fun part! Clear out that 'pass' and type 'move_left()' instead. This is a FUNCTION CALL - it tells you to move left!

preDialogues.name: Maru
preDialogues.content:
Your code should look like this:

def main():
    move_left()

Make sure move_left() is indented under main()!

preDialogues.name: Maru
preDialogues.content: Those tell Python 'execute this function NOW'. Without them, nothing happens. With them, you move left!

preDialogues.name: Maru
preDialogues.content: Once you've written the code, click the PLAY button (green triangle, top-right) to run it!

objectives.description: Click the Play button to run your code
Click the Play button to run your code

postDialogues.name: Qubit
postDialogues.content: Whoa! I moved! The code made me move automatically!

postDialogues.name: Maru
postDialogues.content: SEE? That's the power of programming! You wrote an instruction, and it executed automatically. No clicking required!

postDialogues.name: Qubit
postDialogues.content: Okay, I'll admit... that's pretty cool.

preDialogues.name: Maru
preDialogues.content: Now let's get fancy! You can write MULTIPLE commands, one per line. Try moving right, then up, then left!

preDialogues.name: Maru
preDialogues.content:
Each command should be on its own line, like this:

def main():
    move_right()
    move_up()
    move_left()

All indented under main()!

preDialogues.name: Qubit
preDialogues.content: So it'll execute them in order, top to bottom?

preDialogues.name: Maru
preDialogues.content: Exactly! That's how programs work - they read from top to bottom, doing each thing in sequence. Try it!

objectives.description: Write code with move_right(), move_up(), and move_left()
Run your code to test the movement sequence
Write code with move_right(), move_up(), and move_left()
Run your code to test the movement sequence

postDialogues.name: Qubit
postDialogues.content: That worked! I moved in a pattern, all from code!

postDialogues.name: Maru
postDialogues.content: Perfect! Now you understand the basics. But here's where it gets REALLY interesting - we can automate MORE than just movement...
